repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This PR adds support for C++ scoped enumerations, (`enum class`). Addresses https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/1603.

Workarounds exist for wrapping external C++ enum classes.  These are reported in the issue above. However, they don't solve the following problems:

* The names of the enum values leak into the outer scope as described in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/1603#issuecomment-571415849.
* Converting between Python values and scoped enums requires further awkward workarounds -- see an example of our workaround [here](https://github.com/rapidsai/cudf/blob/branch-0.14/python/cudf/cudf/_lib/csv.pyx#L39-L63).    

This PR addresses the above by adding "true" support for scoped enums.

- [x] Enum classes are defined using `cdef enum class` syntax
- [x] ~Adds a new `CppScopedEnumDefNode` node type~
- [x] Adds a new `CppScopedEnum` PyrexType
- [x] Adds a new `CppScopedEnumScope` for the enum values
- [x] ~Adds utilities `enum.from_py` and `enum.to_py` for converting between Python int-like objects and enum values~
- [x] Adds support for `cpdef enum class`, which generates a Python Enum similar to `cpdef enum`
- [x] Docs

Please note: this is my first time contributing to Cython - please forgive coding faux pas on my part :-)

comment_data.body:
`enum class` seems better here, I think, and should be perfectly backwards compatible.

Also, this should be restricted to C++ mode.
Is a "scoped enum" not an "enum"? I.e. is it better to have separate types and say "or" from time to time, or have scoped enums be a subtype and say "and not" when they should behave differently?

comment_data.body: Agreed - `enumclass` was just easier to add support for quickly, but will change this to `enum class`.

I don't feel strongly here. I can make it such that a scoped enum "is a" enum.

Semantically speaking, I guess the correct thing would be to have `is_enum`, `is_scoped_enum`, and `is_unscoped_enum`, where `scoped_enum` and `unscoped_enum` are the two distinct types of `enum`.

Not advocating for this though, just presenting it as a third option if it's appealing to you :)

+class ScopedEnumType(CType):
+    # name    string
+    # cname   string
+
+    is_scoped_enum = 1
+
+    def __init__(self, name, cname, namespace=None):
+        self.name = name
+        self.cname = cname
+        self.values = []
+        self.namespace = namespace
+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return self.name
+
+    def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
+                        for_display=0, dll_linkage=None, pyrex=0):
+        if pyrex or for_display:
+            base_code = self.name
+        else:
+            if self.namespace:
+                base_code = "%s::%s" % (
+                    self.namespace.empty_declaration_code(),
+                    self.cname
+                )
+            else:
+                base_code = "enum %s" % self.cname
+            base_code = public_decl(base_code, dll_linkage)
+        return self.base_declaration_code(base_code, entity_code)
+
+    def create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
+        if self.from_py_function is not None:
+            return True
+        context = {}
+        cname = "__pyx_convert_%s_from_%s" % (
+            type_identifier(self),
+            "PyObject"
+        )
+        context.update({
+            "cname": cname,
+            "TYPE": self.name,
+            self.name: self
+        })
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
+            "enum.from_py",
+            "CppConvert.pyx",
+            context=context,
+            outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
+            compiler_directives=env.directives
+        ))
+        self.from_py_function = cname
+        return True
+
+    def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
+        if self.to_py_function is not None:

+        context = {}
+        cname = "__pyx_convert_%s_from_%s" % (
+            "PyObject",
+            type_identifier(self)
+        )
+        context.update({
+            "cname": cname,
+            "TYPE": self.name,
+            self.name: self
+        })
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
+            "enum.to_py",
+            "CppConvert.pyx",
+            context=context,
+            outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
+            compiler_directives=env.directives
+        ))
+        self.to_py_function = cname
+        return True

+    def create_type_wrapper(self, env):
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        rst = CythonUtilityCode.load(
+            "ScopedEnumType", "CpdefEnums.pyx",
+            context={"name": self.name,
+                     "cname": self.cname.split("::")[-1],
+                     "items": tuple(self.values)},
+            outer_module_scope=env.global_scope())
+
+        env.use_utility_code(rst)
+

comment_data.body:
@da-woods I'm having some second thoughts here and would love your input:

`CEnumType` inherits from `CIntLike`, and rightly so, as C-style enums are trivially convertible to integers: https://wandbox.org/permlink/b7kkoNz4gI2mjNXx

However, scoped enums are *not* trivially convertible to integers: https://wandbox.org/permlink/2CB5lmrX04rokcT6. So implicit treatment of a scoped enum as an int at the C++ level would likely break things.

As I mentioned [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3640#discussion_r430664189), I think the right semantics could be captured with something like a `BaseEnum` class, and subclasses `CEnum` and `CppScopedEnum`.

Does that sound reasonable?

comment_data.body:
Looking at it again, it doesn't seem completely unreasonable - it obviously has to generate things like overflow-checks so the code is doing more than it initially looks.

However - here's what I'd try:

The conversions go `object -> int_type -> enum` and `enum -> int_type -> object`.
The `object <-> int_type` is taken from `CIntLike` so use their implementation. `create_from_py_utility_code` can become something like:

    def create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
       if self.from_py_function:
            return True
       if CIntLike.create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
           self.from_py_function = 'static_cast<%s>(%s)' % (
                self.cname, self.from_py_function)
       return False

i.e. all you've really done is wrapped the existing conversion in a cast.

It's possible I've missed something important here and it won't work, but I think it's worth a go.

comment_data.body:
I struggled a lot with getting that to work. Below is a summary; perhaps I was missing something obvious:

The problem is essentially making `{{type}}` visible to the utility code. Looking at other examples in the code base, I figured that the `outer_module_scope=` arg here would take care of that:

```python
env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
    "enum_class.to_py",
    "CppConvert.pyx",
    context=context,
    outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
    compiler_directives=env.directives
))
```

However, it fails when the type hasn't been `cimport'd` directly, but rather accessed with `.` notation:

```cython
from cheese cimport Cheese
cdef Cheese d = int(1)  # this worked fine
```

```cython
cimport cheese
cdef cheese.Cheese d = int(1)  # this didn't work 
```

Then, I tried adding the type to the context so that it would be picked up by [`context_types`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Compiler/UtilityCode.py#L79):

```python
context.update(
    {
        ...
        self.name: self # add `self` as a context_type
    }
)

env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
    "enum_class.to_py",
    "CppConvert.pyx",
    context=context,
    outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
    compiler_directives=env.directives
))
```


That resulted in breaking the symbol table entry for the enum. This is where I struggled; I eventually traced it to [this line](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Compiler/UtilityCode.py#L177), where the entry gets overwritten and loses its `enum_values`, breaking things downstream.

comment_data.body:
Yes! Something like this works, except that for `to_py_function`, I needed to get clever and use C++ lambdas, to make a callable that correctly does the two chained casts:

```python
def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):                                                                                                                                            
    if self.to_py_function is not None:                                                                                                                                       
        return True                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
    if self.underlying_type.create_to_py_utility_code(env):                                                                                                                   
        self.to_py_function = '[](const %s& x){return %s((%s)x);}' % (                                                                                                        
            self.cname,                                                                                                                                                       
            self.underlying_type.to_py_function,                                                                                                                              
            self.underlying_type.empty_declaration_code()                                                                                                                     
        )                                                                                                                                                                     
    return True 
```

comment_data.body:
> Does that mean that they are int-like from a Cython point-of-view (even if not from a C++ point-of-view)?

Yes, precisely. C++ enums aren't *trivially* convertible to integers, but can be casted explicitly to their `underlying_type`.

I think it would be more precise here not to make `CppScopedEnumType` be a `CIntLike`, but rather to explicitly call on the functionality of the `underlying_type` when required -- exactly like we discussed [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3640/#discussion_r437339735).

+    def __init__(self, name, cname, underlying_type, namespace=None):

+        self.values = []
+        self.underlying_type = underlying_type
+        self.namespace = namespace
+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return self.name
+
+    def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
+                        for_display=0, dll_linkage=None, pyrex=0):
+        if pyrex or for_display:
+            base_code = self.name
+        else:
+            if self.namespace:
+                base_code = "%s::%s" % (
+                    self.namespace.empty_declaration_code(),
+                    self.cname
+                )
+            else:
+                base_code = "enum %s" % self.cname
+            base_code = public_decl(base_code, dll_linkage)
+        return self.base_declaration_code(base_code, entity_code)

comment_data.body:
I'd rather have it explicit.
```suggestion
    if s.sy == 'class' or (s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'struct'):
```
BTW, I wonder if there's code out there that previously used a `cdef enum struct: ` or `cdef enum struct "some_cname": `.
Maybe we should be nice and keep that name valid, just in case So, if there is a `cdef enum struct` with no name, the user probably meant `struct` to be the name. Difficult to say if that's more helpful, more confusing, or more prone to errors, though

comment_data.body:
Good point. Personally I think we should disallow it. Upon reading `cdef enum struct: ...` one may wonder whether it is:

1. a plain `enum` named `struct`, or
2. an "anonymous `enum struct`"

Of course there is no such thing as (2), but it's not hard to imagine this as being a source of confusion.

commit.message: Add initial support for C++ scoped enums
Use `enum class` instead of `enumclass` to define scoped ennums
Add c++11 tag/compile options to enum class tests
Don't pass context types to enum class utilities
Add support for specifying `underlying_type` of an enum class
Fix scoped enum generation to include underlying type
Move check for empty scoped enum to parsing stage
Fix cname handling for scoped enum items
Merge branch 'add-scoped-enums-support' of https://github.com/shwina/cython into add-scoped-enums-support
Fix bug which skipped last enum entry in scoped enum
Added more tests for scoped enums
Check first if existing entry is a scoped_enum
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/cython/cython into add-scoped-enums-support
Replace assertions with return values in tests
Better names for scoped enum utilities
Try a fix for Py2.7 Cpdef enums
Merge scoped/unscoped enums parsing and Nodes
No need to construct namespace in parser
Don't pass underlying type to declare_enum
Reuse the underlying_type's utility code for scoped enum conversions
Add failure tests for scoped enum coersion
Move empty sue detection to Parser
Merge branch 'add-scoped-enums-support' of https://github.com/shwina/cython into add-scoped-enums-support

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).
